metadata.bible_text: John 20:1-18 (with references to John 16, Psalm 31, Psalm 6, 1 John 3:2, Isaiah 40)
metadata.sermon_start_end: Schottroff: Das Johannesevangelium erzählt, Maria Magdalena sei nach der Hinrichtung Jesu in tiefe Verzweiflung gefallen. Sie läuft noch in der Nacht nach der Bestattung zum Grab Jesu und sieht, dass der Stein, der die Grabkammer verschlossen hat, fehlt. Sie wollte den Leichnam Jesu sehen und ehren und ist nun entsetzt [...] Liebe Schwestern, ihr werdet neue Kraft empfangen, eure Füße werden wie von selbst laufen, und euch werden Flügel wachsen wie den Adlern. Ihr werdet die Männer mitreißen. Wenn ihr mutlos werdet und euch in die Gräber hinabbeugt, dann dreht euch um und seht auf Christus, den Auferstandenen. Er ist bei euch.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: While John 20 is the starting point, the sermon quickly dissolves into a thematic discourse on political resistance and feminism. It fails to identify what is unique to THIS text. Instead, it uses the text as a peg for general socio-political ideas found elsewhere in liberation theology.
quotes: Ich will mit Maria Magdalena weinen über den Tod Jesu... ich will weinen über den Tod von Simon Moegerane...
Der Weg zu den Gräbern der Ermordeten ist der Königsweg von Christinnen und Christen, es ist der Weg von Maria Magdalena.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on the specific Johannine 'Noli me tangere' and the unique identity of the Risen Lord in this pericope rather than equating Maria’s grief with modern political activism.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a clear attempt to provide historical context regarding Roman execution practices and the situation of the Johannine community. However, the exegesis is heavily colored by modern ideological interests (anti-Judaism critique, Roman state terror).
quotes: Tacitus berichtet über die römische Praxis im Zusammenhang politischer Hinrichtungen...
Mit »den Juden« als Christenverfolgern ist im Johannesevangelium nicht das jüdische Volk, sondern die jüdische Führung gemeint.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: The preacher should allow the text's own theological logic to speak before immediately transposing it into a critique of modern German history or South African politics.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is extremely concrete, meeting Dekker's demand for specificity. It addresses the zeitgeist (Chernobyl, Apartheid, feminism). However, it risks becoming a political manifesto rather than a spiritual application of the Word.
quotes: großtechnologische Unfälle wie in Tschernobyl oder bei Sandoz in Basel.
Wer heute weitererzählt, dass es eine Alternative zum Tod gibt, nämlich die Selbstversorgungswirtschaft, der partizipiert an Christi Auferstehung.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the 'extra-territorial' Word of God rather than from a pre-determined political agenda (Self-sufficiency economy).

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is a dialogue (Schottroff/Sölle) which creates a sense of movement, but the exposition is often a mere springboard for long poetic or political applications. The 'present of revelation' is obscured by the dominance of the 'present of the preacher'.
quotes: Ich lese den Bericht über die Tränen der Maria Magdalena... [followed by] ...Manche von uns sind so verzweifelt dass sie nichts sagen können.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: The text itself should 'expound' the hearer, rather than the preacher using the text to expound their own political vision.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery (political oppression, environmental decay) is heavily present. Redemption is framed as 'empowerment' and 'alternative living'. Gratitude is expressed as activism. It is human-oriented, but perhaps too much so, risking a loss of the 'objective' Christocentric pole.
quotes: Tief erschrocken ist meine Seele, denn ich lebe von Ausbeutung.
Auferstehung ist Macht... die den Tod besiegt.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Strengthen the 'Redemption' aspect by emphasizing it as God's act in Christ *for* us, rather than primarily our 'participation' through bread-baking and waste management.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon takes the 'two ways' seriously, though framed as 'logic of death' (capitalism/technology) vs. 'logic of life' (resurrection/vision). The threat of 'being lost in time' (societal collapse) is central.
quotes: Die unendliche Gier führt in den Tod, und die Beschränkung ermöglicht Leben.
Es ist die Vision Gottes... Sein Kind ist gestorben an der Härte des Widerspruchs gegen diese Vision.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Avoid reducing the 'eternal loss' to merely 'temporal/political loss'. The seriousness of the choice should remain rooted in the encounter with the Holy God.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'telos', but the 'two natures' doctrine is undermined by a functional/political Christology. Christ becomes a 'Befreier' (liberator) or a 'brother' whose resurrection is a 'process' we trigger. Grace is equated with political empowerment.
quotes: Christi Auferstehung setzt Auferstehungsprozesse in Gang, zuerst wird Maria Magdalena lebendig...
Gott unser Bruder... Gott meine Schwester...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Re-establish Christ as the 'One Lord' who is God Himself, not just a symbol for human liberation or a 'sisterly' presence.

8_depth_and_length.findings: With an estimated 34 minutes, the sermon provides the 'breadth' Miskotte and Dekker demand. It does not shy away from complex issues, though it lacks the specific exegetical depth of the Greek text.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Use the time to go deeper into the biblical text's own grammar and theology rather than expanding into multiple political sub-themes.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon fails Dekker's criteria primarily by subordinating the specific Bible passage to a pre-existing political and feminist ideology. While it is commendably concrete and respects the 'breadth' required for depth, it treats the Word of God as a resource for human activism rather than a sovereign address. The Christology is functional and the 'One Lord' is obscured by a multitude of human 'visions'.
strengths: Concrete application: It avoids 'general truths' and speaks directly to the zeitgeist of the 1980s.
Seriousness of choice: It presents life as a journey with ultimate consequences (life vs. death).
Length: It allows for a slow, meditative pace that respects the weight of the subject matter.
weaknesses: Lack of Scriptural specificity: The text is used to say what could be said using many other passages or secular texts.
Weak Christology: The 'One Lord' is reduced to a partner in a socio-political 'Auferstehungsprozess'.
Ideological dominance: Dogma and psychology do not 'sleep'; they dominate the pulpit in the form of feminist and liberation theology.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'speech about the gospel and refugees/politics' rather than a sermon in Dekker's strict sense. It lacks the 'nowhere else' quality of the specific text and replaces the 'present of revelation' with a 'present of political mobilization'.
